column8: Intepretation

the regression coefficients are positive. installing a solar panel is expensive, even after tax credits.  The average solar panel system costs $12,810 to install after taxes: https://news.energysage.com/how-much-does-the-average-solar-panel-installation-cost-in-the-u-s/.  Thus, wealthier people are better positioned to cover the upfront costs, and these features either measure or are correlated with the wealth of a particular district

Population density: regression coefficient is negative.  some research suggests that population density is actually inversely correlated with solar PV installated per capita: https://static1.squarespace.com/static/56b25eb9cf80a1861cb737c8/t/5994aaa6e58c62554404bf62/1502915238902/Urban+U.S.+Per+Capita+PV+Usage+-+Population+Density+4-27-17.docx.  The paper suggests that a lack of developable roof space contribues to this under-utilization, and that buildings in cities often absorb most of their sunlight on their facades rather than their rooftops
regression coefficient is positive, even when accounting for income
regression coefficient is positive.  No intuitive explanation of why this would be the case

the regression coefficient is probably positive for the same reason that the regression coefficient is negative for population density (see url above).  It could also be that larger houses are more expensive to heat with solar, making solar panels less viable

the regression coefficients are positive. installing a solar panel is expensive, even after tax credits.  The average solar panel system costs $12,810 to install after taxes: https://news.energysage.com/how-much-does-the-average-solar-panel-installation-cost-in-the-u-s/.  Thus, wealthier people are better positioned to cover the upfront costs, and these features either measure or are correlated with the wealth of a particular district

regression coefficient is negative.  It could be that areas with intense winters can't currently meet their energy demands with renewable energy sources: https://www.forbes.com/sites/christopherhelman/2014/04/24/solar-is-booming-but-will-never-replace-coal/#4d78f6176ebb
no intuitive explanation for why air temperature coefficient would be negative

regression coefficient is negative.  some research suggests that solar radiation is inversely correlated with relative humidity: chrome-extension://oemmndcbldboiebfnladdacbdfmadadm/http://www.ijsrp.org/research-paper-0217/ijsrp-p6246.pdf.  However, it's interesting that this coefficient is still negative even when including solar radiation in the model

regression coefficient is positive.  the amount of solar energy that your system generates depends, among other things, on the number of sunshine hours you get per day and the intensity of the radiation: https://www.solar-estimate.org/solar-panels-101/how-much-do-solar-panels-produce.  Thus, solar panels are more economical in sunnier areas.
it's  odd that the earth temperature coefficient is positive but the air temperature coefficient is negative
interesting that this is significant even after accounting for temperature and froest days
interesting that this is still significant and positive even after accounting for temperature
